data.title: A Guide to Sharon, CT
data.meta_description: Sharon, CT is described as a picturesque New England town in the Litchfield hills of Connecticut. Read about the top attractions in Sharon.
data.text:
Comprising 60 square miles, Sharon is the third largest town by area in Connecticut, and yet one of the least dense in terms of population. The result is a scenic and beautiful pastoral town that is one of the most desirable areas to buy property in all of Litchfield County.

Sharon is notable for a wide inventory of historically preserved antique colonials and farmhouses, as well as large estates. The town attracts affluent residents and even celebrities such as Kevin Bacon, who has a home in the town. Sharon residents have easy access to the Metro North station in nearby Wassaic, NY, which brings you to and from New York City’s Grand Central Station, a journey that takes about 2 hours and 12 minutes. You can read more about the Sharon real estate market in this profile from the New York Times.

Sharon also offers day trippers and tourists plenty of attractions from farm stands, outdoor activities and art. Its location is ideal for easy to access to the Hudson Valley to the west, Berkshires to the north and the rest of Litchfield County to the east and south.

Below we profile the most notable attractions in the town and village of Sharon, Connecticut.

Sharon Playhouse

The Sharon Playhouse is the cultural hub of the town. A regional, non-profit theater with origins that developed from a “play reading group” started in the 1920s, it has been operating for more than 60 seasons in its current building and format. The playhouse features performances with Broadway-caliber actors and talented local performers. Performances in recent years have included Footloose, Anything Goes and Beauty & The Beast. Beyond traditional performances, the theater offers the community children’s programming, theater workshops and other educational opportunities.

While 2020 was a difficult year for Sharon Playhouse (like all theaters and performance spaces) the summer of 2021 looks more promising, with scheduled theater workshops and a youth theater program planned for this summer.

Hopefully as the world returns to normal we will see a full slate of performances scheduled at this community staple in the near future. Keep an eye on their web site for more updates as to when additional performances will be added.

Sharon Historical Society & Museum

Located in a beautifully preserved 1775-built home on Main Street, the Sharon Historical Society & Museum Allows you to explore the 275 years of established history in the area. Permanent collections range from colonial American furniture, iron and iron-industry artifacts, decorative arts and portrait and photo collections from notable local artists. There is also a reading room featuring historic property records in case you want to learn more about the family who lived in the antique colonial home you purchased in the area. Check their web site for current and future exhibits, including the currently running “Road to Women’s Suffrage in Sharon” which features a look at the women who signed a petition for voting rights in 1920.

The Hotchkiss Library of Sharon

The Hotchkiss Library of Sharon is located in an eye catching stone building next door to the Historical Society & Museum and right off Sharon’s green. This makes it the perfect place for residents to borrow a book from Hotchkiss’ extensive collection (you must be a resident of Sharon to use the library’s services) and enjoy it outside in the warmer months. The library offers a wide range of activities and special events for adults and children, including book clubs, a summer book sale and author readings.

Sharon Audubon Center

The Sharon Audubon Center is dedicated to preserving birdlife and the sanctuaries they need to thrive. The center features a network of interconnected trails that connect Bog Meadow Pond to Ford Pond, as well as the visitor center. While the center’s buildings are currently closed due to health and safety protocols, that hasn’t stopped the virtual learning programs and educational workshops to help those interested learn more about the abundant birds and wildlife on the property. A summer camp for kids is also planned for the summer fo 2021.

The Edward

The Edward is a small, sophisticated establishment offering cocktails, wine, beer and small plates and is a great place to visit before taking in a show at the Playhouse. The inside is cozy with bespoke furniture and dark paneled wood. Due to current health and safety protocols, The Edward is offering pod seating inside for one group per evening, so call ahead if interested in visiting. There is also limited outdoor seating on their porch as well as the ability to pick up some menu items.

When Pigs Fly South

Offering authentic southern-style BBQ, When Pigs Fly South has been satisfying larger appetites in Sharon since 2008 and has offered indoor seating since 2013. The Georgia-born owner really focuses on authentic southern offerings from Louisiana Cajun BBQ to Memphis/St.Louis style BBQ ribs. The centerpiece of the establishment is their smoker, which facilitates the authentic BBQ offerings. You can read more about the restaurant experience in this New York Times restaurant review.

JP Gifford Cafe

Every Main Street needs a reliable cafe and that is what you get from JP Gifford Cafe & Catering. Breakfast is generously offered until noon, with selections ranging from classic breakfast sandwiches to the more adventurous pork fried rice and kimchi breakfast burrito. They also offer gluten free and vegan items. Their lunch menu is even more expansive, ranging from hot noodle and grain bowls to a variety of sandwiches, including their signature JP Gifford meatloaf sandwich. The cafe offers a range of pre-made to-go items, as well as basic household staples to hold you over until your next grocery store visit.

Sharon Farm Market

The Sharon Farm Market is the only grocery store within Sharon proper and features fresh, organic locally grown produce as well as arrange of specialty food items. We previously profiled the market in our article on the best grocery stores in Litchfield County.

Standard Space Art Gallery

Sharon attracts many people interested in the arts and culture, with many New York City residents choosing Sharon as a second home. Having a true contemporary art gallery within the town might be expected and the Standard Space delivers for contemporary art lovers. Owner and director Theo Columbe is a notable artist in his own right and launched the gallery in 2017 after moving up from Brooklyn. He uses his gallery to exhibit his own work and champion the work of mid-career and emerging artists, especially from groups historically underrepresented in the art world. In addition to ongoing exhibits, Standard Space offers print sales of work from Columbe, with his focus on sparse, pastoral landscapes, and other artists.

Ellsworth Hill Orchard and Berry Farm

Ellsworth Hill Orchard & Berry farm offers the ideal summertime and fall activities of berry and apple picking on its expansive and beautifully preserved farmland. The farm offers a full range of seasonal activities from an extensive range of apple varieties, blueberries, raspberries, strawberries, cherries, plums, peaches, pears, figs and pumpkins.

Ellsworth publishes a helpful infographic to guide you on what is growing when on their website:

Attribution: Ellsworth Farm – What We Grow

Ellsworth is a great place to bring the kids in the warmer months to learn how food is grown and pick their own haul of fruit to take home. The shop also offers a range of pies, apple cider donuts, farm-made peanut butter, maple syrup and firewood.

Q Farms

If you’re more interested in animals, Q Farms is the place to go. A farm that focuses on ethically raised animals and regenerative farm practices, the attention to detail in how they treat their chickens, cows and pigs is spectacular. The Farm Shop at Q Farms offers residents and visitors a place to purchase healthy, local and nutrient dense foods including pastured pork and 100% grass fed beef. Did we mention they also raise bees? And yes, their organic raw honey is a must try. Visit in person or order online from their web site. You can also find Q Farms products as far away as Columbia University’s Green Market.

Mudge Pond Town Beach

Sharon has a preciously short summer, and during the hotter months you might be in the mood for an old-fashioned, outdoor swim. Luckily for Sharon residents and their guests, Mudge Pond Town Beach is available. The sand beach is raked weekly during the season and the pond features docks, rafts and designated swimming lanes.

Silver Hill Campsite

Sharon residents are lucky to be located along a stretch of the Appalachian Trail, making the area ideal for hiking enthusiasts to hit the trails. The Silver Hill Campsite has been highlighted by the Huffington Post as one of the best “under-the-radar” camping spots in New England. Featuring sunrise views of the Housatonic River Valley, plenty of flat ground to pitch a tent and resources such as a water pump and pavilion for those planning longer excursions along the AT.

Sharon Country Inn

Need a place to stay while visiting (or having family members visit) Sharon? Look no further than the Sharon Country Inn. Featuring accommodations both at its traditional inn and the beautiful new annex, the rooms are serene and spacious and the grounds are peaceful and lush. Along with the Mayflower Inn in Washington, the Sharon Country Inn is one of the best places to stay in Litchfield County.

We hope you enjoyed our guide to Sharon! We will profile more towns and villages in Litchfield County in the coming weeks.
